p.s: The given test is an extract from Shakespeare's play Macbeth Act 1, Scenescene 7)first performed in London in 1606.
The tragedy describes the bloody rise to power and the downfall of the warrior Macbeth.
In this, scene 7 of the first Actact, Lady Macbeth persuades and manipulates her husband into killign the present king of Scotland, Duncan.

At the beginning of the scene, Macbeth voices his worries and says that he does not want to murder Duncan, because the king has shown him respect and he fears for his recently earned good reputation among the people.
Lady Macbeth then accuses him of being a coward and letting his doubts stop him from doing something she deems necessary.
She also links his inability to commit murder to his love for her and how he performs sexually.
Macbeth wants her to stop talking and defends himself by saying that he's already doing everything a man should do.
But Lady Macbeth argues againsagainst that because his conciousness stops him from committing murder.
So she questions his masculinity and ability to do something so cruel.
She continues to manipulate him by emphasizing her own willingness and ambition and insults him forn ot doing as he said he would.
She describes her own ambition through her killing her own baby witha smile on her face if she needed to.
After Macbeth voices his worry of failing, his wife quickly argues that they wouldn't fail if he just found the courage.
Then she continues to plan how they are going to murder King Duncan.
She wants to get the gaurds of his rooms drunk, so that they can easily blamedbe blamed for the murder.
After that Macbeth exclaims that the lady may only give birth to male children since her character resembles more that of a man.
He then finally relents and is willing to commit the crime and to deceive the wordworld.
